body:
I've been meaning to look into MLK for a while now, so thanks for posting this. 

I have verified the source material, and unless Stanford is mis-attributing writings to him, then it is clear that he was a heretic. Tough pill for many to swallow I suppose, because much of what he said was indeed rather inspirational., but then again so is what much of Trump says. 

Nevertheless, their words don't line up with what the bible says and thus one can only assume they don't know God. Even if a person had never read the bible but still knew God, what they would say would not contradict the bible in the way these guys do.

body:
It has nothing to do with general hypocrisy. Christianity is a complete inversion and perversion of the Hebraic religion it claims to fullfill in every sense. There isn't a precept, concept or commandment that isn't utterly misunderstood (willingly of otherwise) and perverted in Christianity. 

The foundational concept of all revelation is to acknowledge and worship the one God alone, and not even that do they observe. And when you fail to obey that most important and clear-cut commandment, everything that comes after is already tainted by the filth of idolatry anyway.

Crying troll instead of having an actual discussion has to be the first and last refuge of the dumb and dishonest online. Try arguing your case instead.

Regardless if MLK was a Christian or just another psuedo-atheist/agnostic secularist using religion to further his political agenda, both those points were correct. And I didn't even bother with the rest. But it's not like Christians ever let truth get in the way of a good story.

post.title: Five Reasons MLK was NOT a True Christian

body:
That's because people like you don't know basic Christian history. The Roman Cathodox Church is the mother church of Christianity. The Eastern Orthodox Church broke off at Chalcedon over  christology, the Eastern Orthodox Church and the Roman Catholic Latin Church separated as the East-West schism, and the Protestant churches and all their daughters broke off from the RCC during the Reformation. 

All of these satanic incarnations of the Nicene mother church acknowledge at least four (two for the Oriental branch) of the seven ecumenical councils as canonical and authoritative, worship the satanic triad-idol as defined in the Nicene-Constantinopolitan Creed, worship the Chalcedonian definition (save the Oriental branch), use the Bible compiled and canonized by their mother Church (the Protestant branches with the Apocrypha removed thanks to the British and Foreign Bible Society in the 19th century), etc. 

The only ones that deny and lie about objective and documented history are para-Protestant types like American style Evangelicals, self-professed born agains, Southern Baptist types, etc., that are as arrogant as they are ignorant, and has an endless supply of fake sages, street preaching clown, self-professed born agains "guided" by the spirit, fake scholars, ignorant pastors, and other clowns and charlatans. The problem is they also use a Bible canon that they don't even know where it came from. They still worship the trinity abomination and the Chalcedonian christology, and constantly use, misuse and misunderstand terminology and concept they don't even know where it came from. They follow a bastardized version of Luther's concept of sola scriptura (and fide for that matter), and the dumbest of them -- perhaps the dumbest people on the face of the planet -- even worship an Anglican translation despite not speaking a word of Greek or Hebrew. 

So yes, it's the mother church of Christianity, but I'm talking about the whole abominable entirety.

body:
Lmao. Isaiah 7 is a prophecy about the fall of the Syro-Ephramite military alligiance during the reign of king Ahaz, 8th century BCE. It's not messianic, it's not about any virgin birth (almah means young woman or maiden), and it's most certainly not about some future pagan God-man and second God. Way to shoot yourself in the foot, polytheist. You've been proven a liar, as I already knew you were. 

And can you even explain the lack of a definite article when the logos is called theos in John's prologue? Of course you can't. Can you explain or even adress John 17:3? Of course you can't. Can you even define what a son is or decide if Jesus is God's son or God #2? Of course you can't. 

Keep crying about trolls now, polytheist. Exposed.

Do you use a 66 or 73 book Bible canon, yes or no?

The most formative period of Christianity started with Constantine's alleged conversation at the Battle of the Milvian Bridge 312 AD, followed by the Edict of Milan 313 AD, then the start of state endorsed ecumenism with the First Council of Nicea 325 AD. body:
> The Ebionites appear to have understood Jesus not as the Messiah but as a prophetic precursor who heralds the coming kingdom of God on Earth in which two human Messiahs (a Davidic king and an Aaronite high priest) and/or an angelic Messiah (a cosmic judge of the Earth from heaven known as the "Son of man") will reign forever. Consequently, Jesus is believed to have come to fulfill a threefold mission: 1) teach all Israelites to live immediately according to a radical ethic of inward and outward righteousness that will be standard in the Messianic Age; 2) complete the work of Moses by calling for the abolishment of animal sacrifices during a cleansing of the Temple; and 3) die as a moral exemplar (rather than as a substitutionary atonement) to move Israelites to the repentance necessary for personal atonement and national redemption in order to prepare for the world to come.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ebionites#On_Jesus_the_Nazarene

> And they were right about Paul.

What about Paul and Peter is apostate? Are you suggesting that because they made mistakes, they're damned without mercy? By that logic every single person is apostate with no hope at all. And I suppose that must include James, who supported Paul.

> And if any version of Matthew is edited it's the canonical Greek version.

You have absolutely no evidence for that claim. We have many very old copies of the gospels, and they almost all show amazingly little variation. All text types agree with our version of Matthew, not the Ebionites. The Ebionites' version was clearly the outlier here.

body:
> God's day will arrive regardless.

But you don't believe in it, so why are you telling it to me?

> Can you even define what a son is or decide if Jesus is God's son or God #2? Of course you can't.

There's where we disagree. You think "son" necessarily means son in the strictest, most literal sense of the term. However, we can't comprehend what this type of son is describing and that's why it is not told. Clearly, it can't be the exact same type of son you're thinking of, because biologically He is Mary's son.

Here is an image of the earliest extant manuscript of John 1, which declares "the word WAS God", and that this word was "manifest in the flesh and dwelled among us": https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/58/Papyrus_66_%28GA%29.jpg

It was probably written by John or someone very close to him, unlikely to be Paul and if it was Peter he obviously got along with John, so your argument that Peter and Paul are frauds doesn't dismiss the evidence this time, unless of course you think John is an apostate too.

He's describe as "the light" and the creator as well. I think that's pretty clear.

You are full of pride and love to mock those who disagree with you. You don't sound like you follow Jesus. You sound more like one of the stuck up Pharisees, who were ultimately the main culprits behind His crucifixion.

In any case you're making this all out to be a much bigger deal than it actually is. The sonship isn't really described for a reason, because our minds can't comprehend it, we were given the two/one commandments to do for now, and we know what was done for us.

I never said such a thing. I said by your logic of "son" you should consider it so.

> and God is called ha/ton theos.

It depends on the noun case and the writing style. Articles are sometimes used with titles and names, but other times they are not.

But I should warn you that your pride and superior attitude right now is a direct violation of that very same commandment.

No, polytheist, he was put to death for no crime, he didn't claim to be any pagan God-man, and if he did, he would be a false prophet per definition, and his execution just. And they conspired against him because he was gathering a following, and they feared he would incite an uprising causing the Romans to intercede.

Did I say anything about "picture words"? Literally all I did was quote the text. You're just trying to avoid answering the question

What question, polytheist?

In Mark 1:1 there is no article either

What about it, polytheist? What are you even on about? This is your brain on idolatry and satanic filth.
